comments.author: Maria Ferguson

comments.text:
~*SPOILERS*~ Earlier in the film, Billy misses an audition for the Royal 
Ballet School. His teacher confronts his family about this, who, being 
primarily blue-collar working men in the middle of a strike, react about as 
well as you'd expect to the realisation that their son/younger brother had 
been secretly learning ballet, and they warn the teacher not to speak to 
him again. This clip happens later in the film, and in the following scene, 
you see that the father runs directly to the teacher's house to enquire how 
much the audition would cost.

Hope that helps :)
comments.author: EggFriedSpam

comments.text:
I have to disagree... he might not be disappointed but confused. Watching 
all that talent coming out right on his face and still fighting against his 
own beliefs... That must be a whole confusing experience, breaking out the 
tabu of being a male dancer means being homosexual, BUT his son and his 
bravery standing proud and strong doing what he loves, demonstrating he's 
talented and somebody needs to believe in him. Just sayin.
comments.author: Omar Laguna

comments.text:

comments.text:
The first time I saw this scene was the almost open-mouthed at the sight of 
Billy eventually dancing as a professional.
It's an ugly taboo to think that only girls who like ballet or men who 
dance are gay. I think Billy expresses much diversity both in dance and in 
his friendship with his friend Michael.﻿

comments.text:
His dad experienced an up-welling of emotion that he just couldn't suppress 
(like he usually does, or else morphs it into rage). And of course he was 
raised to be a "hard man", and so crying in front of anybody, let alone 
your son, was not on his agenda. I know jack shit about cinema, but I know 
this is a very powerful scene!!﻿

comments.text:
How come with this movie they auditioned hundreds of boys to find someone 
who could both dance and act and yet in Black swan they get a dance double? 
True his technique isn't perfect, but he has potential and energy and 
Jamiemhad been dancing since he was six (he's about 14 here and yes that is 
his real accent) and in his next movie he was able to transform himself 
into a cripple (Nicholas Nickleby 2002). Training for a year and a half 
does not make you a professional ballerina (re Natalie Portman)﻿

comments.author: EuskaltelEuskadi

comments.text:
I have a friend who did ballet from the ages 3 to 16, until she quit just 
because her new teacher was too mean, and it made her dislike going to 
classes. I come from a poor background and could not afford lessons, would 
have given anything to take her place. It's a shame how I am now in a 
position to afford classes and shoes, but ballet takes years of sculpting 
the body and balancing it. I sometimes do ballet as exercise. Dance is 
beautiful, if you want to do it, find a way.
comments.author: Ro .s

comments.text:
I want my future son to join Ballet. Even if he looses interest in it after 
a year or two, I want to give him the opportunity to achieve this level of 
excellence, gain this stamina, confidence, elegance and culture. Ballet is 
not just for girls, and I think people need to start realising that.

comments.author: MangoClownfish

comments.text:
A reexamination is forced, and the true character of the townsfolk is 
revealed. What at first seemed little better than the confines of a prison 
settlement, turns out to be the home of gut-wrenching human re-examination, 
and true self sacrificing love; rising out of pretence, amidst externally 
imposed and unavoidable despair. By contrast, the supposed refuge, the 
haven of the arts, home to creativity and free expression itself, is 
revealed to be cheap in character and lacking itself...
comments.author: MangoClownfish

comments.text:
It reminds me of the town I grew up in. A prevailing attitude that the Arts 
are for girls to perform in church, while the men earn their keep day after 
day going down the the mine shaft, the only so-called enrichment in their 
lives, what they're bred to do - a true literary and social tragedy on the 
rape of human legitimacy, in every respect of itself, in which everyone is 
being screwed. Then seemingly out of nowhere, despair itself, a determined 
someone challenges every assumption there is...
comments.author: MangoClownfish
